import plotly.express as ply

import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

source.ee78c1d6: **Now lets plot the Petal Width as a continuos color scale for these data points on the plot.**
source.3cba91de: **Lets look at petal details species wise.**
source.bb9a26ee: **Sepal detail Scatter Plot With variable size depending on Petal Length (since it was the most variable/inconsistent i.e. had maximum standard deviation)**
source.9a28f50a: **Now lets facet the graphs based on species.**
source.e1de4bc8: **Leaving Sepal Width which is the most consistent out and putting color and symbol as species we get this.**
source.7c167d3f:
**Entries = 150 ||| 
  No null values are also 150 in all 5 columns so no need to check on the null values and their columns.**
source.0603017c: **Letas look at sepal details species wise.**
source.a0c22507:
**Petal Length seems to vary the most whereas Sepal Width seeems to be the most consistent across the 3 species of iris flowers going by their standard deviation from mean (std).**

**Going by the respective mean values the flowers seem to have leaner and shorter petals than sepals.**
source.b28ac836: **Clearly petal details give a better and distinctive identity to the species of the flower , hence from now we will use the petal map and plot sepal details over it**
source.4dedc824: Lets use the sepal scatter plot and try to plot petal details above it one detail at a time.
source.9f93bdda: **Sepal Width is the most consistent so we will use it for color and not size.**
source.ec46dcc2: We will only be doing EDA so no need to make train and test (and valid) datsets separate in this.
